awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Dynamic Clustering and Rheology of Magnetic Janus Particles with Shifted Dipoles
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of the project is to engineer the flowability of a fluid, i.e., the ease with which a fluid flows, by addition of active magnetic particles with unique magnetic properties. These particles can be manipulated by a combination of an external magnetic field and an internal chemical gradient. Fluids with varying flowability are important for common technologies, such as printers, fluid shock absorbers, fluid property sensors, biomedical devices, and body armor. Control of the flowability will enable longer lifetimes, broader applicability, reduced cost, and increased stability of the fluids and devices. The proposed research will investigate the assembly properties of active magnetic colloids using experimental and computational techniques. Additional benefits of these studies are the creation of a toolbox for the design of fluids that have their flowability tailored to a particular application.   

The research addresses the need for an in-depth understanding of the assembly behavior of active magnetic Janus particles with shifted dipoles. In systems with shifted dipoles, the magnetic dipole axis is shifted away from the center of mass of the particle, thereby providing additional control over particle orientation and response. In combination with on-board propulsion, particles with shifted dipoles represent a new and exciting class of active materials. The research described will advance our understanding of magnetic particle interaction, active matter, and the rheology of complex magnetic fluids. This work will enable future studies in which, for example, Brownian Dynamics simulations are used to predict long-time dynamics and to discover novel structures that are difficult to accomplish or detect experimentally. More broadly, research described in the proposal will advance our understanding of the intrinsic role of forces and torques in the structure of complex fluids, thus providing important insights into the statistical physics of out-of-equilibrium systems and enabling researchers to better engineer and utilize many body dynamics in the microscopic regime. The educational goals of this proposal will leverage the collaborative environment between the two participating institutions to enhance student education at various stages and thereby strengthen the diversity of the STEM workforce pipeline.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report for Grant #:1705565

The research goal of the NSF-CBET 1705565 grant was to gain a better understanding of the properties governing the behavior of magnetic Janus particles with shifted dipoles. The educational goal evolved around offering of research opportunities that increase the participation and competitiveness of students from underrepresented groups at the City College of New York (CCNY) and the City University of New York (CUNY) and provide international research experiences for students.

For the accomplishment of these goals, three objectives were identified: (1) Quantify 2D -assembly of Janus particles with different shifted magnetic dipoles using optical microscopy and Langevin dynamics at the particle interaction level. (2) Quantify impact of enhanced diffusion through self-propulsion on 2D chain formation and stability. (3) Quantify effect of structures formed by active magnetic Janus particles on 3D suspension rheology and colloidal stability using rheological measurements and Brownian Dynamics simulations.

New Instrumentation and Techniques: Two Brownian dynamics simulation codes were developed; one of the codes predicts the self-assembly of magnetic Janus particles and provides structure phase diagrams, while the other analyzes the behavior of bottom-heavy Janus particles near walls. Further, a python-based tracking software was developed that processes recorded videos of aggregating colloidal particle systems in order to extract concentration profiles and energy landscapes. A microscopy cell has been designed that enables observation of active Janus and patchy particles at liquid/liquid interfaces.  

Research Findings and Outcomes: The research performed under the award has generated a generally applicable capture-distance model that provides insight into the experimental field-directed self-assembly of magnetic Janus particles with parallel and radially shifted dipoles. The model is a first step in predicting the behavior of magnetorheological fluids comprising magnetic Janus and patchy particles. Janus and patchy particles are designer building blocks with a priori designed magnetic properties. Understanding of the structures formed and our ability to design particles to from specific structures will be a necessary input for machine learning approaches to connecting assembled structures to the viscosity, i.e., flowability, of the resulting magnetic colloidal fluid. Our collaborator at UPRM has developed a Brownian Dynamics (BD) method to catalog predictable and repeatable structures of magnetic colloids that can be synthesized in the laboratory in form of phase diagrams. Further, the BD simulations have provided an approach to promote the growth of aggregates as well as break them based on the self-propulsion of the particles, opening the door for study of smart materials. While comparison of BD simulations was found to agree qualitatively, more work is needed to quantitatively predict experimentally observed assembly rates. As particles often encounter boundaries in experimental systems, research also explored the hydrodynamic interaction of Janus and patchy particles with nearby solid and liquid boundaries. Our experiments and simulations with self-propelled particles discovered that interfaces increased swimming velocities of Janus and patchy particles, self-propelled particles can exhibit stable sliding states at horizontal walls above them despite the presence of sedimentation forces, and self-propulsion prevents particles from entering interfaces.

Educational Impact: The grant provided research opportunities for five undergraduate, one MS, and six PhD students in the Chemical Engineering program at the City College of New York. Support of this project provided a year-round mentoring program for CCNY undergraduate and MS students from underrepresented groups. 10 students (3 summer students) from underrepresented groups met with the PI on a weekly basis to discuss academic progress, career plans, graduate school applications and research opportunities. Five undergraduate students and one MS students participated in the mentoring program of whom ~40% have moved on into PhD programs and ~20% will be applying for PhD programs.

Dissemination Efforts

Peer-reviewed publications: 7 published, 2 in preparation

Invited Talks: 6 

Conference Talks: 19

Conference Posters: 7

Human Resource Development (brackets indicate students from underrepresented groups)

PhD students involved in research: 6 (5)

MS students involved in international research activities: 1 (1)

UG students involved in research activities: 5 (4)

UG students, who continued in PhD programs: 3 (3)


Last Modified: 05/29/2023
Modified by: Ilona Kretzschmar

Red - experimental data, Green - Smoluchowski coagulation equation least-squares fit, Blue - dashed - Brownian, dash-dotted - magnetic, and solid - capture distance model predictions. Most prominent aggregation events contributing to concentration shown as insets.
    Thomas Long

    Capture Model Fit for Magnetic Janus particles
  • Left: Diffusion coefficient of inactive Pt-coated silica Janus particles in liquid interface (orange) vs near a solid wall (blue). Insets show particle position relative to interface. Right: Optical microscopy images of inactive and active Janus particles at and near water/oil interface, respectivel
    Zohreh Jalilvand
    Copyrighted
    Ilona Kretzschmar
    Behavior of Active Janus Particles near Solid and Liquid Boundaries
  • Structurally rich "phase" diagram for magnetic Janus particles with a radially shifted dipole obtained at long times as a function of magnetic field strength and dipole shift using Brownian Dynamics simulation.
    Ubaldo M. C�rdova-Figueroa

    Ilona Kretzschmar
    Phase Diagram of Magnetic Janus Particle Structures Predicted by Brownian Dynamics Simulation
